Die in Frankreich seit den frühen Studien von Bourdieu und Passeron geführte Auseinan dersetzung um soziale Ungleichheit und deren Reproduktion ist vor allem aufgegriffen in der  Frage nach dem angemessenen Umgang mit Kindern und Jugendlichen, die nach Frankreich mi griert sind und/oder dort aufwachsen und die offenbar häufiger auf Schwierigkeiten in der Schu le stoßen.  »Selbst wenn sie in Frankreich geboren wurden und die école maternelle  besucht haben,  sind die enfants immigrés häufiger vom so genannten échec scolaire , dem schulischen Schei tern, betroffen« (Sievers, 2009, S. 50 mit Bezug auf INSEE 2005, 98). Offenbar geht der Anspruch auf gleiche Bildungschancen und gleiche Behandlung nicht ohne Weiteres in den schulischen Praktiken auf. 13 »Selbstverständlich sind die Lehrer der Republik  trotz Gesamtschule auch heute mit großer sozialer Ungleichheit, ungleichen Schulinteressen und deren schulischer Reproduktion konfrontiert. Kein anderes Thema behandelt die französische Bildungsforschung so unablässig wie dieses Problem« (Flitner, 2012, S. 276). Der Anspruch einer egalitären Bildung für alle scheint schwierig einzulösen, gestaltet sich  als spannungsreich und wird noch verschärft durch diverse Maßnahmen zur Rekrutierung von Eliten (Hörner, 2004, S. 157). Frankreich zeige »eine Schullandschaft, in der das Schicksal für die Elite und die breite Masse am weitesten auseinanderklafft« (Delory-Momberger, 2012, S. 18). 14 7. Zum Schluss: Unterrichten als Kern von Schule und Schulentwicklung Das französische Schulwesen ist geprägt durch eine sich vereinzelt transformierende, aber doch weitestgehend zentralistische staatliche Obhut. Einerseits ist damit die Ganztagsbetreuung von Kindern und Jugendlichen gewährleistet, andererseits bietet diese Struktur für die Entwick lung von Schulen bloß beschränkte Spielräume (Bonnet, 2002). Lehrersein und Schülersein ist in Frankreich mit spezifischen pädagogischen Erwartungen und Zuständigkeiten verbunden (Sie vers 2009, 31). Allerdings können diese mit ersten Erkenntnissen aus der interpretativen Unter richtsforschung zum Handeln und zu sozialen Praktiken von schulischen Akteuren in Frank reich auch relativiert werden (Meister, 2012; Schelle, 2012). Beobachtungen deuten darauf hin, dass sich auf der Ebene der Mikroprozesse, ähnlich der These der Universalisierung der moder nen Schule bei Adick (1992), neben Unterschieden (was z.B. die Rolle der Beweisführung betrifft, vgl. Knipping, 2003) universelle Praktiken und Aushandlungen, etwa im Umgang mit Gegen ständen und offenen Lernarrangements zeigen (Schelle, 2016). Differenzierte Erkenntnisse über Schule in Frankreich sind auf Studien angewiesen, die sich dem Geschehen an Schulen in Frank reich und den Deutungen widmen, die die Akteure in ihren Praktiken zum Ausdruck bringen. 13 Zum Umgang mit Diversität und Denkmustern von Lehrpersonen in Frankreich siehe Sievers, 2009;  zu biografischem Werdegang, Diversität und Mehrsprachigkeit in der Schule siehe Delory-Momber ger, 2012 sowie Kunkel & Stratilaki, 2012. 14 Da es etablierte umfangreiche nationale Evaluationen (und vor allem die mehr oder weniger öffen tlichen concours ) gibt, wird Studien wie PISA (Mons & Pons, 2012) weniger Bedeutung zugemessen  (Schmidt, 2003) bzw. beleben diese bloß vorhandene Reformdebatten (Hörner, 2003, siehe hier zu auch Delory-Momberger, 2012, S. 15ff.) und Debatten zur Reproduktion sozialer Ungleichheit  (Mons & Pons, 2012). Das Weitergeben und Kopieren dieses Dokuments ist nicht zulässig.  Matti Rautiainen and Emma Kostiainen School in Finland 1. Introduction   The outstanding performance of Finnish students in international comparative studies such as  PISA and TIMSS was the main reason why Finland became the focus of international interest in the 2000s and acquired the nickname “PISAlandia” – the country which everybody interested in education wants to visit and learn the secrets of its magic schooling touch. PISA tourism has brought numerous of visitors from all over the world to Finland to study and copy the Finnish way of education. Although the essence of education is general intellectual capital, which knows no borders, education is always linked to a given society and its values. In this sense, the trans ferability of education is a complex issue, since educational cultures are developed over tens and hundreds of years and display an abundance of historical characteristics, not all of which are easy to identify as such. In this chapter, we will provide an overview of the contemporary ed ucational system in Finland and examine some of the challenges and guidelines for the future. 2. The educational system There are certain basic principles which are fundamental to the Finnish educational system and which are reflected by every approach to education. In most sources describing the Finnish edu cational system, these foregrounded principles are equity in education, high quality in education, as well as trust and responsibility as a foundation of the educational system (see Finnish Edu-cation in a Nutshell, 2012; Hautamäki et al., 2008; Kupiainen, Hautamäki & Karjalainen, 2009; Sahlberg, 2004; The Finnish National Board of Education, 2015). Equity in education  is the framing principle in the policy and structure underlying the Finn ish educational system.  The basis of the Finnish school system is formed by a compulsory nineyear period of basic education for all children aged between seven and sixteen. At the beginning of 2015, a new modified Basic Education Act came into force, with the result that pre-prima ry education for six-year-old children, which had previously been voluntary, became compulso ry. The goal of pre-primary education is to provide all children with an equal start by promoting their good development and learning opportunities (National Core Curriculum for Pre-Primary Education, 2010). Finnish educational policy calls for the support and provision of special needs education primarily within mainstream schools (Finnish Education in a Nutshell, 2012). The fo cus is on early intervention, and this “stepped-up support” is the primary form of support that is provided before the time comes to make an official decision about whether a child needs special education (Pesonen et al., 2015). The high quality of education  in Finland is attributed mainly to the country’s highly edu cated teachers. The teaching profession has managed to maintain its popularity among appli cants at all times. The academic status of teacher training is held in high regard and a mas ter’s degree is a prerequisite for finding employment as a teacher. Universities can select the best teacher candidates from among a large group of applicants: only 10 to 15 per cent of applicants for primary school teacher training are accepted (Kupiainen et al., 2009). Research is integrat ed into the education of teachers in two ways: teacher training in itself is an object of study (e.g.   Handbuch Schulpädagogik, 9783825286989, 2018   wurde mit IP-Adresse 131.188.006.020 aus dem Netz der UB Erlangen-Nürnberg am Februar 17, 2023 um 09:18:04 (UTC) heruntergeladen.  Das Weitergeben und Kopieren dieses Dokuments ist nicht zulässig.  School in Finland237 Hökkä & Eteläpelto, 2014) and the aim of the curriculum is to develop a research-oriented at titude (Aksela, 2010; Niemi, 2008). Academic research is an essential feature of teacher train ing and it prepares teachers to think analytically and critically and to utilise research findings  in their work (Jakku-Sihvonen, 2008). Research-based teacher education develops teachers’ abili ty to share knowledge and ideas in the professional community and thus solve various problems they face in their work. This can be interpreted as showing that the principles of equity and  consistent quality in education have been implemented well in the Finnish education system. It is therefore common practice for children to go to the school closest to their homes regardless of the family’s social background. Trust and responsibility as a foundation of the education system  is manifested at the individ ual and institutional as well as the national levels. When comparing global educational trends, two special characteristics emerge: (1) in Finland there is no comprehensive nationwide test ing, and (2) standards for schools, teachers, and learning are flexible and open to local variation (Hautamäki et al., 2008; Sahlberg, 2004). The first and only national examination applying to the entire educational system is matriculation at the end of general upper secondary school. The educational system in Finland is a mixture of state-controlled and locally determined  autonomous features. The Ministry of Education drafts legislation and the general objectives of education are outlined by the government. The Finnish National Agency for Education, in turn, is responsible for drawing up the national core curriculum. Then follow the local authorities, municipalities, principals, and teachers, who have a certain amount of autonomy in planning the practical schooling arrangements and formulate their own curriculum based on the national core curriculum (Hautamäki et al., 2008). The trust in local authorities offers opportunities for variations and diversity in educational solutions and practices that best suit the particular profile which individual schools wish to emphasise. Trust and responsibility go hand in hand. When lo cal agents are trusted, they are more willing to take responsibility for providing good quality in education. Students too are given responsibility: for example, in general upper secondary school, the large majority of the students can choose their individual study schedules. Furthermore, the trend whereby curricula at different levels of education are changing and becoming more phe nomenon-based than content-based promotes and underlines the students’ own interest in learn ing. Although entering education at different school levels is flexible and equal and the major ity of Finnish youth is well-educated, the unemployment rate among young people is showing a slight increase. In 2017, the unemployment rate for young people aged 15 to 24 was 20.1 per cent, which was the same as the year before (Statistics Finland, 2017). The cross-administrative youth guarantee programme, which took effect from the start of 2013, is one expression of how responsibility is taken for young people in Finland, ensuring that they have access to education and preventing them from becoming unemployed or excluded from society (The Youth Guaran tee in Finland, 2012). Although the Finnish educational system emphasises equity, quality, and trust with its vari ous supporting structures, the system requires continuous development and the crucial areas re quiring improvement must be identified, acknowledged and critically evaluated. 3. Basic education in Finland 3.1 Two turning points The history of education in Finland can be divided into three different periods (Valtonen & Rau tiainen, 2012). Two turning points are especially significant from the viewpoint of basic educa tion. The Tsar of Russia, Alexander II, charged the senate of the grand duchy of Finland with de veloping the Finnish school system. As a result of this change formal schooling spread all over Finland and gave all children, boys and girls, the possibility of basic education. The change was   Handbuch Schulpädagogik, 9783825286989, 2018   wurde mit IP-Adresse 131.188.006.020 aus dem Netz der UB Erlangen-Nürnberg am Februar 17, 2023 um 09:18:04 (UTC) heruntergeladen.  Das Weitergeben und Kopieren dieses Dokuments ist nicht zulässig.  School in Finland239 radical not only because it included girls, but also because schooling became available to chil dren from all social classes. At the same time Uno Cygnaeus (1810–1888), the architect of this  radical change, founded the first teacher training college in Jyväskylä in 1863. This college of fered two training programmes from the very outset: one for men and the other for women. The pedagogical thought of Uno Cygnaeus has inspired generation after generation and re mains one of the most popular themes in the field of education history research in Finland. His educational legacy in Finland is enormous: his plan for primary school still forms the founda tion of basic education today. Cygnaeus thought it important to study arts and crafts in school besides academic subjects. This idea was carried over to the new comprehensive school in the 1970s, and arts and crafts have a strong position among school subjects especially in the prima ry school. Nevertheless, the entire educational system was old-fashioned in the 1950s and came under  increasing critical fire in the 1960s, when left-wing politicians demanded radical reforms that would create greater equality in the system, especially basic education. The resulting educational reform, which was one the most radical in Europe, replaced the old parallel system with a nine-year period of compulsory schooling for all children. Teacher education was also reorganised. The primary teacher training programme became a master’s degree programme. Additionally, in the 1970s teacher training departments took over the pedagogical training of subject teachers.  The nature of school changed with the reform. Cygnaeus’ elementary school was based on  a strong ethos of citizenship, nation, and society. The nine-year compulsory school replaced this with an emphasis on how well individual students achieved the objectives set for each sub ject. The teachers’ primary task became to guarantee that all students attained a certain level of learning in school. This focus explains why the differences between schools are small and is also one reason of the reasons for Finland’s considerable success in international learning result surveys. Finnish schools are primarily learning centres for goals set in the curriculum. Never theless, the culture of participation in school is limited and students have few opportunities for contributing to the decision-making process. 3.2 New national core curriculum 2016 – new school? As a product of Finnish welfare state ideology, the Finnish school system differs from other Nordic school systems. Radical reforms created equality and the new requirements for primary school teacher qualifications ensured the availability of highly educated and professional teach ers throughout Finland. One result of the nine-year compulsory school was that post-secondary education also improved. Since the 1970s, educational policies have aimed at providing either vocational or academic training for all citizens. Finland has a well-educated population and in recent decades there has been a rising level of regard for education in Finnish society. Nevertheless, the desire to change compulsory schooling has been growing in recent years  for a variety of reasons, one of which is the poor levels of participation mentioned above. Ac cording to EUI (Economist Intelligence Unit) measurements, Finland is one of the most dem ocratic countries in the world. In contrast, though, both teacher and student participation at Finnish schools is poor. While teachers have a high degree of pedagogical autonomy and profes sional confidence, their everyday work has been based on individual accomplishment, and team work and collaboration among teachers are still in their infancy.  In addition, there has been increasing criticism of the fundamental task of the school –  that of facilitating learning. Although Finland has achieved outstanding results in international learning surveys, all schools are challenged by the issues of collaborative learning and phenom  Handbuch Schulpädagogik, 9783825286989, 2018   wurde mit IP-Adresse 131.188.006.020 aus dem Netz der UB Erlangen-Nürnberg am Februar 17, 2023 um 09:18:04 (UTC) heruntergeladen. One perspective on new learning  environments is the use of ICT in learning processes. The standard of ICT equipment in schools is rather good, but it is still used rather infrequently in teaching  (Survey of Schools, 2013 ). How to meet these challenges? The new 2016 national core curriculum for basic educa tion sets a new course for primary and secondary schools. The framework for what happens in schools is defined by legislation and the national core curriculum, the essence of which must be transferred to the schools by creating and developing new practices in school culture. The 2016 national core curriculum is sustained by the relationship (and the tension) be tween individual and community. The learner’s individual role at the centre of the curriculum will remain, but the curriculum also emphasises the responsibility of individuals for the com munities and the society to which they belong. Global responsibility too is more prominently visible than in the earlier 2004 curriculum. One of the central concepts is eco-social education, which emphasises our responsibility to ensure that future generations too will be able to enjoy our high standards of living. All these themes have a connection to the challenges facing the  edu cational for implementing democracy and participation in schools. Another main theme in the national core curriculum is the clarification of the meaning of learn ing in each subject. Beside normal school subjects, students study integrated cross-curricular topics. The starting points for these cross-curricular topics are phenomena that transcend the boundaries of various subjects. In addition to what has been mentioned above, the new curricu lum lays more stress on arts and crafts, physical education, social studies, value education, and environmental education than the previous curriculum.  The nature of the new curriculum demands a new school culture and a new way for teachers  to work collaboratively. The new aim can be described in terms of the concept of “transformative   Handbuch Schulpädagogik, 9783825286989, 2018   wurde mit IP-Adresse 131.188.006.020 aus dem Netz der UB Erlangen-Nürnberg am Februar 17, 2023 um 09:18:04 (UTC) heruntergeladen. This means that teach ers must reclaim the real nature of the teacher’s profession, which is intellectual and not that of  a “technical expert” who performs didactical tricks in school. Instead of providing simple and clear solutions, teachers, should discuss and carry out experiments concerning the essential na ture of school, such as why schools exist in the first place. According to the new 2016 curricu lum, the guidelines for developing school culture are:  –Learning organisation as a core of school culture;  –Welfare and safety in everyday life;  –Interaction and diverse working;  –Cultural diversity and language awareness;  –Participation and democracy;  –Parity and equality;  –Responsibility for environment and sustainable development. 4. Challenges of creating a new operational culture   in the Finnish school system The obvious strengths of the Finnish education system can become obstacles to improvement if the system relies on its principles too confidently. A well-functioning system may even obscure the features that need to be enhanced. In addition to the matter of good practices, there is a se rious need to acknowledge two prominent issues in particular that concern the challenges in volved in changing school culture. First, schools and educational institutions need to be more bold and open in adapting. Fin land is a representative democracy, a society where it is typical to carry out an experiment on a small scale initially and, if it works, to extend it across the entire society. However, at present there are not many experiments in educational development taking place in Finnish schools. In order to improve pedagogy and move it towards the competencies modern society requires, the frequency and scope of these experiments and innovative pilot projects must be significantly in creased. Even if Finnish teachers have considerable autonomy in their work, it is rare to find dif ferent ways of teaching and working in schools. In other words, Finnish teachers do not take risks; rather, they socialise themselves into the tradition that the majority of schools and teach ers represent. Developing education requires constant work and an open-minded attitude with a perspective extending from the present and near future to the long-term future (Rautiainen & Kostiainen, 2015; Jääskelä, Klemola, Kostiainen & Rautiainen, 2012). Second, Finnish schools need to improve participation (see Rautiainen & Räihä, 2012). There  is a demand for education which focuses on developing schools as communities with strong net works that include stakeholders from different sectors of society. Learning processes should sup port learners so that they can participate actively in creating the best learning environments and, consequently, a culture of participation as well. School architecture and new technolo gy play an important role in the construction of modern participatory learning communities (Jääskelä et al., 2012).  Given the challenges that confront the entire educational system from pre-education to  higher education, teacher education has an extremely important role to play in imparting new ways of learning, teaching and working. For example, the Department of Teacher Education at the University of Jyväskylä switched from a content-based to a phenomenon-based curriculum in 2014. Matti Rautiainen and Emma Kostiainen242 “The Teacher Education Department implements a phenomenon-based curriculum: the goal  of studying is an attempt to understand the phenomena and problems related to learning. This requires the ability to combine various scientific theories and authentic viewpoints de riving from everyday experiences because the phenomenon of learning cannot be profound ly understood from a single viewpoint” (Curriculum plans 2014–2017, p. 1). The Department of Teacher Education at the University of Jyväskylä is not the only institution in  Finland which has adopted a phenomenon-based curriculum in recent years. Another is Alppila secondary school in Helsinki. Bold experiments like these are also beginning elsewhere in Fin land, reflecting a new development in the country’s educational culture. There is at least one big difference compared with previous changes in the history of education in Finland. Reform today is more of a continuing process than a rapid reform. It is our opinion that this change reflects the new way of developing education in democracies – through bottom-up experiments.  References Aksela, M. (2010). Das Weitergeben und Kopieren dieses Dokuments ist nicht zulässig.  Kristen Nawrotzki School in the USA 1.  Introduction Public schools in the USA, like their counterparts in many other parts of the world, are in the  midst of profound transformation. Some of the many changes have come about in response to demographic pressures; others, meanwhile, are the result of new technologies, some of which have radically altered the physical and pedagogical experience of classrooms or have even re placed classrooms altogether. Of all the factors influencing the ongoing transformation of US public schools, one stands out as definitive: federal government involvement in schooling.  Under the US Constitution, the federal government has no authority over education. In stead, everything from paying for school buildings to licensing and hiring teachers to the devel opment of curricula and standards rests with the education authorities in each of the fifty states. Many decisions are taken at the local level, where the country’s 15,144 local education authorities (“school districts” or “systems”) are run by boards of locally-elected or appointed administra tors. Most school districts provide public schooling at levels ranging from kindergarten through twelfth grade (K-12), roughly corresponding to ages five to eighteen. Forty-two states plus the District of Columbia also offer at least some state-funded pre-kindergarten (pre-K) education for children aged three or four; state-funded pre-K programmes enrol nearly one-third of four-year-olds (Barnett et al., 2016). Altogether, US public schools educate approximately 50.4 million pre-K-12 students, and they do so in ways that are fundamentally unequal. A key source of inequality in American education lies in school funding. The vast majori ty of the costs of public schooling are covered by combinations of state funds and money from locally-determined property taxes, with the latter typically varying widely from district to dis trict (National Center for Education Statistics, 2016). Although numerous states have instituted reforms to redistribute funding across districts in the interest of equality, local control of local funds remains sacrosanct in much of the country (Baker, Sciarra & Farrie, 2012). Thus there re main wide-ranging discrepancies in funding levels within and across states, with some districts spending two or three times as much as others (Jackson, Johnson & Persico, 2015). Moreover, districts have traditionally relied on (racially and socioeconomically homogenous) neighbour hood catchment areas for the assignment of children to primary and secondary schools, leading to what amount to racially and socioeconomically segregated schools. All too often, racial and ethnic minority children in poor neighbourhoods have been afforded a poor education in un der-resourced schools in low-budget districts (Howard, 2015). Despite states’ and districts’ staunch defence of their respective power over public educa tion, federal government involvement in many aspects of schooling has vastly increased in the last sixty years. In important ways, federal government interventions have transformed the du ties of school districts and the work of schools and teachers, in terms of the students served and the types and quality of education provided to them. Over the last sixty years, the federal gov ernment has sought to reduce inequality and increase quality in three key ways: first, through enforcement of racial desegregation and “catch-up” programmes; second, through federal legis lation promoting, or requiring states to broaden, school access; and third, through the raising of standards and accountability. However, the new Trump administration has signalled a dramatic change in the quality and scope of federal educational intervention, one which is likely to trans form the federal relationship to schools as much as the schools themselves. Racial desegregation and “catch-up” programme s There had been trickles of support from the federal government to schools before the 1950s,  such as when the Department of Agriculture began distributing surplus commodities to schools to provide lunches for poor children in the Depression years of the 1930s. 1 But it was not until  the 1950s and 60s, in response to the intensified activism and legal victories of the Civil Rights Movement, that the taboo of federal intervention in schools was broken. This began in earnest in the aftermath of the 1954 US Supreme Court decision in the case of Brown v. Board of Edu cation, which ruled that racially segregated schools were inherently unequal and therefore in vi olation of the “equal protection” guarantee of the Constitution’s Fourteenth Amendment. Seg regationist leaders in southern states where the racial apartheid system had been enshrined in law refused to comply with federal orders to desegregate schools. This led President Dwight Ei senhower to authorise the use of federal troops to ensure access for black students to formerly white-only schools.  Ongoing state and district-level resistance to school desegregation through the 1960s and  beyond meant continued federal involvement in enforcing judicial rulings and monitoring the racial integration of public schools. A series of 1960s Civil Rights Acts empowered the feder al government to take additional steps to monitor desegregation in schools and to file lawsuits where schools were not being integrated actively or quickly enough. As things turned out, deseg regation was a battle the federal government would wage for decades but never actually win, due to overt resistance (especially by white people, who choose private schools or moved to whiter neighbourhoods) and to the persistence of housing segregation.  While in the midst of desegregation efforts, the US federal government took another, gi ant step toward intervening in schools. Shock over the USSR’s launch of the Sputnik 1 satellite prompted the federal government to pass a law offering money to high schools and other institu tions specifically to improve the teaching and study of mathematics, natural science, and mod ern foreign languages – all justified under the rubric of national defence. The new civil rights laws of the 1960s allowed the federal government to withhold federal money from schools which fell afoul of those laws’ stipulations – including those in northern states where racial segrega tion was common in practice although not rooted in law. This combination of the carrot and the stick – a financial inducement toward a specific educational programme or service deemed to be in the national interest (known as “categorical aid”), paired with the threat to withhold fed eral money from schools not playing by federal rules – has formed the basis for federal involve ment in schools (and in higher education) ever since. State education agencies and districts can, in theory, decline some categories of federal funds in order to be free from the associated reg ulatory constraints. However, most rely significantly on such monies, which in 2016 amounted to 8 per cent of per student expenditures in public schools (US Department of Education, 2016); this means they are either practically or politically unable to provide services out of state and lo cal funds alone. The watershed of federal intervention into public schools came in 1965 in the form of the  education-specific legislation as part of President Lyndon Johnson’s wide-ranging War on Pover ty welfare programmes. Riding a new wave of social-scientific analysis of poverty and its caus es (O’Connor, 2001), the Elementary and Secondary Education Act (ESEA) was to set the stage for the next thirty-five years of federal involvement in public schools. The ESEA’s Title I offered federal money to schools serving large numbers (or percentages) of poor children, money which  1 The Department of the Interior’s separate Indian Schools and the Department of Defense’s system of  schools for military dependents are special cases excluded from the present discussion. The ESEA also provided funds to help the then-modest state education agencies expand in size and expertise so that they could manage the distribution of federal funds and monitoring of Ti tle I schools (Vinovskis, 2009). As pleased as schools were to receive the carrot of federal mon ey, they still bristled over the stick of federal – and state – involvement in their institutions, and in particular over the strings attached to the money they received. Numerous reauthorisations of the ESEA through the 1990s attempted to increase the impact of Title I programmes while al lowing schools more freedom in using the funds, but debates over the ESEA’s reach into schools and classrooms continued. Although schools and districts could decline the money in order to free themselves from the associated constraints, few have been wont to do so given the sums in volved. 3. Civil rights and school access In the 1970s, the expanding movements for civil rights led to new, even more sweeping pieces of federal education legislation pertaining to public schools. The most important extended pub lic schools’ duties toward students whom they had often neglected in the past, including girls and students with special needs. These new laws spelled out increasingly numerous and specif ic requirements for local schools to fulfil if they wanted to continue to receive any federal funds, changing not only the schools’ clientele but the schools themselves as well.  Girls’ education received a boost as part of the Education Amendments Act of 1972, whose  Title IX raised the spectre of the stick (that is, the withdrawal of federal funding) for any edu cation programme discriminating on the basis of sex. Title IX included protections against sex ual harassment in schools, called for the equalisation of schools’ investment in girls’ and boys’ sports, and resulted in greater access for girls to the full range of school courses and subjects previously considered appropriate for boys only. Two years later Congress passed the Equal Edu cational Opportunities for All Act, an amendment to the ESEA, which comprehensively forbade discrimination on the basis of national origin, race, colour, or gender. Here, too, there was wide spread criticism not only of the law’s insistence on gender equity, but also of the federal govern ment’s over-reach in imposing rules about the workings of schools at the local level, rules that would prove costly to follow (Cole, 1976). Such criticism notwithstanding, the federal government intervened again in schooling in  1975, again with a view to defending civil rights, when Congress passed the Education for all Handicapped Children Act (EHA). This was the result of increasing disability rights activism and court decisions invoking the equal protections cited in the Brown v. Board of Education case  for children with disabilities. At that time, only 20 per cent of children with disabilities attended public schools, and many of those were not given the support and therapies they needed to actu ally benefit from instruction (US Department of Education, 2010). What is more, it had become apparent that schools’ procedures for determining (dis)ability were biased against children from racial and ethnic minority backgrounds, with the result that disabled children from such back grounds had been disproportionately segregated from other students (Connor & Ferri, 2005). Thus the Act required states and local authorities to provide all disabled children – then estimat ed to number eight million – with access to “free appropriate public education which empha sises special education and related services designed to meet their unique needs” (Education for All Handicapped Children Act, 1975). This revolution in the education of children with special needs placed immense burdens on local school budgets and personnel, whom it charged with everything from the identification of disabilities to the design and implementation of individu  Handbuch Schulpädagogik, 9783825286989, 2018   wurde mit IP-Adresse 131.188.006.020 aus dem Netz der UB Erlangen-Nürnberg am Februar 17, 2023 um 09:18:04 (UTC) heruntergeladen.  Das Weitergeben und Kopieren dieses Dokuments ist nicht zulässig.  School in the USA247 alised education plans for children and youth aged three to twenty-one. The legislation guaran teed federal funding of only 40 per cent of the excess costs, leaving schools to cover the rest out  of their own (state and local) funds.  As with Title IX’s protections against discrimination on the basis of sex, it would take many  years (and many court cases) for districts and schools to make real progress toward fulfilling the EHA’s mandate, which was reauthorised and strengthened as the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA) in 1997 and again in 2004. The reauthorisations expanded the EHA to re quire public schools to educate children in the least restrictive (that is, the most inclusive) pos sible environment, and to include services for children under age three and for children placed by parents in private schools. Philosophically speaking, the laws’ insistence on the education of all children (known as the “zero reject” policy) marked a major sea change in the understand ing of schools and their responsibilities to society at large (Ladenson, 2005). In practical terms, it brought radical changes to teachers’ work in classrooms and to schools’ work in their communi-ties, with their responsibility ultimately extending to children from birth to age twenty-one, and including children in private schools as well. Although there had been units (e.g. of the Department of the Interior) concerned with ed ucation since the nineteenth century, there was not a cabinet-level Department of Education (DoEd) in its own right until 1979, under President Jimmy Carter. DoEd’s stated purpose was and is “to ensure equal access to education and to promote educational excellence throughout the nation”. It does so by implementing categorical aid programmes, by collecting data and by overseeing and promoting research and research-based reforms. Its Office for Civil Rights is one of the nation’s largest and most important civil rights agencies. However, the DoEd’s foundation did not mean an immediate increase in federal interven tion in public schools; to the contrary, financial constraints and the conservative policy prefer ences of the Ronald Reagan and George H. Bush administrations meant that the 1980s and early 1990s saw a lessening of federal intervention in public schools (with the exception of the afore mentioned IDEA) and a reduction in the regulations tied to existing programmes (Elmore & Fuhrman, 1990). Reagan even campaigned to abolish the DoEd, but later changed his mind. As the federal government stepped back in this period, there was a substantial increase in state-lev el involvement in public schools, not least in response to demands by business interests and the public for state action at a time when test scores suggested that local schools were failing to properly educate many children – especially those from poor families, living in poor neighbour hoods, and going to low-budget (and still racially segregated) schools. These state-based efforts, while substantial, made little improvement in educational outcomes (Stanford Center for Educa tion Policy Analysis, n.d.). 4. Standards and accountability – at all costs? With laws guaranteeing access to public schools in place, and amidst increasing concern about the quality of US education in international comparison, federal policy attention at the start of the twenty-first century turned to focus on the “educational excellence” component of the DoEd’s mandate. It did so most notably (and aggressively) in the first George W. Bush adminis tration in the form of a dramatic revision to ESEA 1965, which passed as the No Child Left Be hind (NCLB) Act of 2001. NCLB aimed to narrow “the achievement gaps between minority and nonminority students, and between disadvantaged children and their more advantaged peers” (No Child Left Behind Act, 2001, Sec. 1001), and sought to do so by holding individual schools directly accountable for their students’ skills and progress. In other words, as a matter of nation  Handbuch Schulpädagogik, 9783825286989, 2018   wurde mit IP-Adresse 131.188.006.020 aus dem Netz der UB Erlangen-Nürnberg am Februar 17, 2023 um 09:18:04 (UTC) heruntergeladen.  Das Weitergeben und Kopieren dieses Dokuments ist nicht zulässig.  Kristen Nawrotzki248 al interest, the federal government would no longer allow state and local education authorities to  bungle disadvantaged students’ education.  Since the 1990s the states had been working both separately and in concert to develop  standards and increase accountability, but NCLB went much further. Under the law, states had to develop “challenging” state-wide standards (in particular for reading and mathematics) and to devise and administer state-wide regimes of yearly standardised tests to determine wheth er and how well schools (that is, teachers) were doing their job. They also had to guarantee that all teachers were highly qualified in the fields in which they taught and that students made “ad equate yearly progress” in standardised test scores. Failure to achieve said progress meant pen alties for schools, many of them costly. These ranged from allowing pupils to transfer to another (presumably more effective) school to replacing teachers, introducing a new curriculum, or ex tending the school day or year. After five years without adequate yearly progress, schools faced complete restructuring, including replacing teachers, the takeover of the school by the state or by a private management company, or even school closure. All of this meant, of course, increased federal control as well as increased state control over who was doing what in local schools. Given the radical nature of NCLB as an extensive federal intervention into local public  schools, it is no surprise that it faced widespread criticism. Federal funding for K-12 education rose in the wake of NCLB, as Title I programmes continued and state education authorities re ceived grants to develop and implement testing regimes. Nevertheless, the bulk of the econom ic burden of NCLB fell on states and districts. Furthermore, an entire school would be penal ised if any subgroup of students failed to reach standards or continually improve – including disabled students. Struggling schools serving high-poverty populations were arguably harmed by having to enact the required remedies out of their already constrained budgets. Moreover, it soon became apparent that the high stakes of NCLB testing regimes created perverse incentives for teachers and schools to improve test scores at all costs, with negative effects on teachers and students alike. Ultimately, nearly half of all US public schools were identified as “failing” under NCLB, including many considered high quality by other measures (Dillon, 2011). School districts paid more for education under NCLB, but the return on investment was low given the – at best – mixed results in terms of improved test scores (Strauss, 2015). As a result of protests from states, districts, teachers’ unions, and parents around the coun try, President Barack Obama waived elements of NCLB from 2010 onward, lessening the strict accountability and penalties, offering states and schools more flexibility in adapting to local con ditions, including exempting some students from testing. He allowed states to opt out of NCLB in 2011, a step taken by a majority of states soon thereafter. There was a string attached, how ever: states receiving waivers had to agree to develop and adopt common standards rather than the state-specific ones already in place. In essence this forced states to adopt the Common Core standards (and associated tests), which had been developed beginning in 2009 by a coalition of forty-two states with the support of the DoEd. These standards for mathematics and English were (and are) hotly debated, both for their ambitious content and for their being more or less imposed from above. In 2009, President Obama underscored federal support for the Common Core by approving competitive, limited-term grants which offered a total of $4.35 billion worth of federal carrots to the states agreeing to specific school reforms, including adopting the Com mon Core (or similar) standards and assessments, instituting performance-based teacher evalu ations, and building data systems to track student progress. Most states applied for the grants, and those that received them from 2010 to 2014 educated nearly half of all US K-12 students. The DoEd’s reach continued to grow. Tellingly, the NCLB’s replacement, the much less prescriptive Every Student Succeeds Act  (ESSA) of 2015, marked the first lessening of federal power over public schools in over 30 years. School in the USA249 To the relief of many, ESSA gave more control of schooling back to districts and shifted ac countability assessment from the DoEd to the states, while ending and expressly prohibiting the  DoEd’s promotion of the Common Core or any other common standards or curriculum between the states. While standards have now been handed back to the states, most have stuck with the Common Core so far: as of late 2016, thirty-six states (and the District of Columbia) were fol lowing Common Core standards, nine had announced a major revision of replacement of the Common Core, four states never adopted it, and one adopted only the standards for English (Ujifusa, 2016). Regardless of the standards states follow, ESSA, like its predecessor, requires an nual tests of all children in grades three to eight. 5. The limits of federal intervention and support for choice Since the 1950s, then, the federal government has intervened in public schools on a massive scale. It has done so intending to force states and districts to resolve persistent and pernicious problems which localities and the states would not or could not deal with. Despite massive long-term local resistance, there have been successes: federal desegregation orders and legislation such as Title IX’s gender equity requirement and the special education provisions of EHA and IDEA vastly increased the educational opportunities afforded to many Americans. At the same time, there have been some major failures, too, including the persistence (or resurgence) of de facto ra cial segregation and the crash and burn of the NCLB – both of which are tied to the structur al inequalities still embedded in the catchment-area intakes and property-tax-based systems of funding of local schools. The largely bi-partisan federal efforts to ensure universal access to high-quality public ed ucation increased state-level control and came at the expense of local determination of the fun damentals of schooling, including who teaches what to whom, how, and why – and even then, high-quality education seemed to be in short supply. To many Americans, federal assertiveness thereby “inexorably transform[ed] public schools from intimate community assets into complex, impersonal, rule-driven institutions” which neither represent local priorities nor do well by their students (Hill, 2000, p. 11). This understanding of public schools as “intimate community assets” is essential to US culture even as it masks and perpetuates profound inequalities of education funded and administered at the local level. How can one be sure that one’s own (child’s) interests will be served? The answer, many Americans have come to believe, is choice.  “Choice” in this sense refers to parental decision-making power to opt out of one’s neigh bourhood public school and to send a child to some other institution at the public’s expense. In generations past, parents dissatisfied with their neighbourhood primary or secondary school might have applied to the school board for a change of school, paid for a private school, or ar ranged to home school. Some might have had access to a magnet school with a particular pro file designed to attract students from across catchment areas. For the vast majority, however, the neighbourhood school was their only option, leaving many children trapped in poor, undera chieving schools. Why not free parents to choose the school they think is best for their child?  Various state-level efforts to expand parental choice since the early 1990s have sought to  create educational marketplaces in which public schools exist as consumer options from which all parents can choose. They have been largely based on the neoliberal assumption that giving parents the liberty to choose gives them access to better schools while also spurring healthy competition between schools seeking parents’ favour. Here, the neoliberal belief in market dis cipline has gone hand in hand with the belief that government regulation should be rolled back, if not eliminated entirely, so that the open market can function properly. For a time, there was   Handbuch Schulpädagogik, 9783825286989, 2018   wurde mit IP-Adresse 131.188.006.020 aus dem Netz der UB Erlangen-Nürnberg am Februar 17, 2023 um 09:18:04 (UTC) heruntergeladen.  Das Weitergeben und Kopieren dieses Dokuments ist nicht zulässig.  Kristen Nawrotzki250 great hope amongst both Republican and Democratic leaders that school choice would spur edu cational innovation, raise the quality of public schooling by making teachers and school admin istrators beholden to parents as consumers, and reduce educational inequality. Of these, the first  has come to pass, the second has been only patchily realised, and the third appears to be more distant than ever. Most of the innovation that has taken place is the result of charter schools, which have rap idly reshaped the educational marketplace in forty-three states and the District of Columbia. The structure and regulation of charters differ by state, but in general they are limited-term per formance-based contracts between the state (normally authorised by local school boards) and groups of people such as parents or teachers, or even non-profit and for-profit corporations. The charter allows each group to operate a publicly funded school based on their own plan and with out many of the strictures binding traditional public schools. Like traditional schools, charter schools cannot reject students on the basis of disability, age, gender, race, religion, or ethnic or igin, and they receive funding according to the number of students they enrol. (Places in over subscribed schools are distributed by lottery.) Unlike traditional schools, charter schools are be holden to the market: if a school does not attract enough students, or if dissatisfied parents pull children out, a school will lack the funds to stay open. Moreover, if a school’s students do not do sufficiently well on state-mandated tests, its charter might not be renewed.  Although charter schools emerged in part as a reaction against federal intervention into lo cal education, in fact they owe their popularity to successive federal administrations in the 1990s and 2000s, which offered money to states willing to experiment with charter schooling. This support appeared first as an amendment to the ESEA in the Clinton administration in 1994, and then in the Charter Schools Expansion Act in 1998. Both NCLB in the early 2000s and to day’s ESSA continued federal grants designed to help state education agencies regulate and pro mote the founding of charter schools. Today, charter schools make up 15 per cent of all US pub lic schools. More than half of them are in urban areas, and poor and racial and ethnic minority students are overrepresented among charter school pupils (Berends, 2015; National Center for Education Statistics, 2016). While charter schools continue to spread rapidly, they remain high ly controversial for a number of reasons, including wide variations in school quality, the rap id rise of for-profit charter school corporations, and evidence that school choice in general and  the presence of charter schools in particular have increased rather than decreased educational    inequality, and harmed civil rights (Lubienski & Weitzel, 2010; Orfield & Frankenberg, 2013; Ravitch, 2016). 6. Conclusion: marketisation and the demise of federal intervention Whereas the DoEd under President Obama was particularly vigorous in its approaches toward increasing access, accountability, and school choice, President Donald Trump’s DoEd appears keen to focus primarily on the latter. His Education Secretary, Betsy DeVos (who famously has no personal experience of public schools whatsoever) is known as a champion not only of char ter schools but also of vouchers, which expand free market competition among schools by allow ing parents to use public money to pay for private schooling – including, most controversially, at religious schools. Since the 1990s, voters in 14 states and the District of Columbia have approved voucher programmes, most but not all of which are provided as part of special programmes for poor children, those attending failing public schools, or those with disabilities (National Confer ence of State Legislators, 2017). School in the USA251 Critics of vouchers draw on many of the concerns expressed about charter schools and  school choice in general while also pointing to an increasing body of research showing that stu dents using vouchers do not learn more or better than at public schools (Carey, 2017). This is es pecially grievous in the case of children and youth with special needs, who forfeit federal IDEA  protections when enrolling in private schools, even with public vouchers (Goldstein, 2017, n. p.). For them and other students long seen as in need of protection, the important education-access and civil rights victories of twentieth century federal educational intervention are being undone by the neoliberal reforms of the new administration. What is more, President Trump has pro posed cutting existing federal education programmes, perhaps as a step towards eventually clos ing the DoEd altogether. While the latest proposals have not yet been enacted, their message is clear: not only is  choice is good, but more choice is better. Public schooling is no longer understood as being in the public interest per se. The quasi-privatisation of public schooling is presented as a potential solution to the many failures of US public schools, even as it disables or evades those federal in terventions shown to protect civil rights and to improve the education and life chances of the most marginalised and disadvantaged students. Granted, US public schools have never been fair and equal in their distribution of educational opportunity, but the decades of federal govern ment interventions made equality a goal, even if a distant one, and measurably moved the na tion’s decentralised education system in the direction of improvement. In the new educational marketplace, however, federal interventions are seen as fetters, and it will be left to private enter prise to determine the quality, shape, and purpose of educational provision in a context in which equality and equity do not even come into the picture. Das kanadische Schulsystem  Das kanadische Schulsystem ist, ähnlich dem deutschen, dezentral organisiert. Die Bildungsver antwortung liegt bei den zehn Provinzen und drei Territorien. Sie sind für die Bildungspläne,  (Abschluss-)Prüfungen und methodisch-didaktische Anregungen (»instructional frameworks«)  verantwortlich. Daneben überwachen sie die Ausund Weiterbildung der Lehrer und die Infra struktur von Schulen (z.B. Büchereien, Schulverpflegung, Transport der Schüler) (www.ncee.org).  Ein zentrales Bildungsministerium für Kanada existiert nicht. Dennoch arbeiten die einzel nen Bildungsministerien bei der Erarbeitung von Bildungsstandards und »best practice«-Beispie-len eng zusammen und nutzen die Ergebnisse der jeweils anderen als Benchmarks, um politische Entscheidungen vorzubereiten und gemeinsame Initiativen durchzuführen. Besondere Schwer punkte liegen im Bereich der Lehrerbildung, der Entwicklung von Curricula sowie der Integra tion von Schülern mit Migrationshintergrund, da Kanada sich als Einwanderungsland versteht und seit Jahrzehnten weltweit zu den Ländern mit den höchsten Zuwanderungsraten gehört. Die Zusammenarbeit der Provinzen wird vom Council of Ministers of Education, Canada (CMEC)   organisiert und unterstützt, in dem alle Bildungsminister kooperieren (www.cmec.ca).  Das kanadische Schulwesen ist von altersstufenbezogenen, aufeinander folgenden Schularten  geprägt. Die Stratifikation erfolgt demnach nicht nach dem Leistungspotenzial der Schüler, son dern nach deren Entwicklungsphase (Kindheit, frühe Adoleszenz, späte Adoleszenz). Die jewei lige Schulstruktur ist regional historisch gewachsen, folgt aber heute in ganz Kanada einem ver gleichbaren Grundmuster. Sie gliedert sich in eine Grundschule mit Vorschule und einer bzw. zwei Sekundarschulen,  d.h. einer secondary school  bzw. einer middle school und einer high school . Kanadische Schulen  sind in der Regel inklusiv, sodass Kinder und Jugendliche mit unterschiedlichen Lernvorausset zungen durch Formen der inneren Differenzierung gemeinsam beschult werden.  Die Grundschulzeit beginnt mit dem kostenfreien Vorschuljahr (kindergarten)  für fünfjäh rige Kinder, für das ein auf spielerischem Lernen basierender Bildungsplan bereits einen starken Fokus auf die Kompensation herkunftsbedingter Bildungsbenachteiligung in den Bereichen »Li teracy« und »Numeracy« legt (Alberta Education, 2008). Die Teilnahme am Vorschulangebot ist freiwillig, wird aber de facto von mehr als 95 Prozent der Eltern wahrgenommen (www.statcan.gc.ca). In Stadtteilen und Orten mit einer bildungsbenachteiligten Bevölkerung (»sozialer Brenn punkt«) wird seit 2010 ein weiteres kostenfreies Kindergartenjahr bereits für Vierjährige angebo ten, sodass Kinder in diesen Stadtteilen vor dem Eintritt in die erste Klasse zwei Jahre intensi ver Förderung durch professionell ausgebildete Fachkräfte erfahren (www.education.alberta.ca/admin/supportingstudents). Nachdem die Vorschule bis 2012 weitgehend als Halbtagsprogramm angeboten wurde, ist sie mittlerweile in den meisten Provinzen zu einem Ganztagsangebot aus gebaut worden (bspw. www.education.alberta.ca/parents/ecs, www.cbe.ab.ca/programs/kinder garten/).  Auf die Vorschule folgt gemeinhin die sechsjährige Grundschule. Die Finanzierung des Schulsystems obliegt den einzelnen Provinzen und Territorien, die  den Schulämtern und diese wiederum den Schulen direkt Budgets zuweisen, ohne Landkreise oder Städte mit zur Finanzierung zu verpflichten. Dabei erfolgt, in deutlich höherem Maße als in den USA, auch ein Finanzausgleich, der Schulen in sozioökonomisch benachteiligten Stadt teilen und Regionen gezielt Mittel zukommen lässt, um zur Kompensation sozialer Disparitäten beizutragen (bspw. Pollock 2013; www.ncee.org). Allen Schülern wird so eine kostenfreie und im internationalen Vergleich hochwertige Schulbildung ermöglicht. Etwa 90 Prozent der Schüle rinnen und Schüler nehmen diese Möglichkeit wahr – nur etwa 10 Prozent der Kinder und Ju gendlichen besuchen private Schulen. Die meisten privaten Schulen sind in katholischer Träger schaft. Sie werden vom Staat mitfinanziert und nehmen heutzutage auch Kinder unabhängig von deren religiösem Bekenntnis auf. Vereinzelt existieren auch andere Privatschulen, im Vergleich zu den USA und Großbritannien ist deren Anzahl jedoch gering. Zur Finanzierung des Schul wesens wendet Kanada 6,8 Prozent des Bruttoinlandsprodukts (BIP) auf. Dieser Wert übersteigt  den Durchschnitt der OECD-Länder (6,1  %). I n Zahlen bedeutet dies, dass pro Schüler in weiter führenden Schulen jährlich $11.607 ausgegeben wurden, während dafür im OECD-Durchschnitt $9.506 zur Verfügung stehen (www.ncee.org).  Auf der internationalen Ebene nahm Kanada bereits in der ersten PISA-Studie 2000 einen  führenden Platz ein, der auch dadurch geprägt war, dass Schüler unterschiedlicher sozioökono mischer und ethnischer Herkunft statistisch gesehen im internationalen Vergleich geringe Leis tungsunterschiede zeigten. Diese positiven Ergebnisse bestätigte Kanada in den darauffolgenden PISA-Studien nicht nur, sondern verbesserte sie sogar in einigen Provinzen, vor allem in Alberta im Westen und in Ontario im Osten (www.ncee.org).  2. Pädagogische Fachkräfte an kanadischen Schulen  Die Möglichkeit, in Kanada Lehrerin oder Lehrer zu werden, ist durch ein selektives System be schränkt, das darauf ausgerichtet ist, nur sehr qualifizierte High-School-Absolventinnen und -Absolventen zum Lehramtsstudium zuzulassen. Der Lehrerberuf ist in Kanada beliebt, nach gefragt und im internationalen Vergleich auch gut bezahlt, sodass in der Regel das Interesse der Bewerber das Angebot an Studienplätzen deutlich übersteigt. Die jeweiligen Zulassungsvoraus setzungen regelt jede Provinz bzw. jedes Territorium individuell. Bewerberinnen und Bewerber werden in einem schriftlichen Test und Interviews geprüft. So wird für die jeweilige Provinz eine Lehrlizenz erworben, die auf Ethical Standards und professionellen Teaching Standards aufbaut. In der Bezahlung wird kein Unterschied zwischen den Lehr kräften mit einem Schwerpunkt auf Elementarbildung (Vorschule und Grundschule) oder der  Bildung von Jugendlichen (Sekundarschule) gemacht. Alle Lehrkräfte durchlaufen eine gleich wertige universitäre Ausbildung und verdienen daher das gleiche Grundgehalt. Der Anstieg des Gehalts basiert auf Weiterqualifikationen, zum Beispiel durch ein zusätzliches, spezialisierendes Masterstudium sowie auf der Berufserfahrung der Lehrkräfte. Auch die Übernahme zusätzlicher Aufgaben, bspw. im Verwaltungsbereich einer Schule, wird monetär vergütet. Darüber hinaus besteht die Möglichkeit, zusätzliche Benefits, wie ein Sabbatjahr oder die Freistellung zu einem weiterführenden Studium zu verhandeln (www.ctf-fce.ca). Ähnlich der Karriereentwicklung in anderen führenden PISA-Ländern besteht auch in Ka nada die Möglichkeit, durch Fortbildung, innerhalb der Schule sowie innerhalb des Schulsystems berufliche Positionen mit gesteigerter Verantwortung zu übernehmen. Auch für Lehrkräfte, die kein Leitungsamt anstreben, schaffen die professionellen Teaching Standards klare Anreize zur professionellen Weiterentwicklung (www. oct.ca). Chancengerechtigkeit, Diversität und Inklusion  Die zunehmende gesellschaftliche Anerkennung von »Diversität« als Wert und Leitbild der ka nadischen Gesellschaft trug dazu bei, dass sich das Schulsystem landesweit vergleichsweise früh und systematisch der Herausforderung der Inklusion als möglichst umfassender gesellschaftli cher Teilhabe benachteiligter Gruppen stellte (Burke & Milewski, 2012):  –Aufgrund von Menschenrechtsklagen wurde Schülerinnen und Schülern mit Behinderung vor dem kanadischen Verfassungsgericht bereits in den frühen 1970er-Jahren das Recht auf inklusive Beschulung an Regelschulen zugesprochen. Nach einer von kontroversen Diskus sionen geprägten Übergangszeit in den 19070erund 1980er-Jahren wurden die staatlichen Sonderschulen sukzessive weitgehend aufgelöst und durch »special needs education« an den staatlichen Primarund Sekundarschulen ersetzt.   –Anschließend an die Bürgerrechtsbewegung und gestützt durch empirische Bildungsstudien entstand ein politisches Bewusstsein für die Problematik einer strukturellen Bildungsbenach teiligung der indigenen Bevölkerung Kanadas, der sogenannten »First Nations«. Infolgedes sen wurden systematisch bildungsund sozialpolitische Maßnahmen ergriffen, um die Bil dungschancen von Kindern aus First-Nations-Familien zu verbessern.   –Darüber hinaus wanderten seit den 1970er-Jahren verstärkt Personen aus unterschiedlichen asiatischen Kulturen ein, wodurch sich die sprachliche, religiöse und kulturelle Zusammen setzung der Schülerschaft an kanadischen Schulen sehr stark wandelte.  Als Reaktion auf diese »neue Diversität« (Sliwka, 2010) der Schulen wurden im Lauf der Jah re verschiedene Innovationen eingeführt, die auch Ansatzpunkte für die Lösung gegenwärtiger schulstruktureller und schulkultureller Herausforderungen in Deutschland bieten.  Im Gegensatz zum deutschen Schulsystem, das noch immer stark an der sozialen Bezugs norm 2 orientiert ist, betont das kanadische Bildungssystem die Ausrichtung der Leistungs bewertung und Leistungsrückmeldung an der individuellen und kriterialen Bezugsnorm3. Es  entspricht nicht dem kanadischen Verständnis von Chancengerechtigkeit, Kinder, die sich her kunftsund sozialisationsbedingt in ihren Lernvoraussetzungen stark voneinander unterschei den, schon in jungen Jahren dem direkten Vergleich auszusetzen.  Unter dem Leitbild » Assessment is for Learning « (deutsch: Leistungsrückmeldung dient der  Förderung von Lernen) werden die Bezugsnormen adaptiv so eingesetzt, dass sie die Motivati on in Lernprozessen unterstützen. Formative Leistungsrückmeldung, die den Lernprozess in den Mittelpunkt stellt und dem Schüler und seinen Eltern nicht bloß eine Note, sondern vielmehr differenzierte und lernprozessbezogene Informationen zur Verfügung stellt, gehört zu den wirk samsten Interventionen in Lernprozessen (Black & Wiliam, 2009, 2010; Marzano, 2006; Stiggins, Arter, Chappius, J. & Chappius, S., 2006; Hattie, 2012). In mehreren Provinzen wird die Kompetenzstufe 3 dabei als »provincial standard « beschrie ben, d.h. als Standardstufe, die möglichst viele Schülerinnen und Schüler durch eine passgenaue Förderung erreichen sollen (bspw. www.education.alberta.ca). Das Erreichen dieses Kompetenz-niveaus wird als Voraussetzung dafür gesehen, dass eine Schülerin oder ein Schüler als Erwach-sener ein ökonomisch eigenständiges und politisch selbstbestimmtes Leben in der kanadischen Gesellschaft führen kann. Dazwi schen dienen flexible Lernstandserhebungen und andere Testinstrumente dazu, die Entwick lung einzelner Kinder systematisch zu dokumentieren (Alberta Assessment Consortium, o.J.). So verfügt jeder Einzelschüler über eine fünf stellige Zahlenkodierung. Testergebnisse werden nicht direkt mit einem Schülernamen versehen. Nur die jeweilige verantwortliche Klassenlehrkraft und die Schulleitung kann die Testergebnis se den Schülernamen zuordnen. Diese führen strategi sche Planungsgespräche mit den Schulleitungen in ihrem Distrikt. Die Schulleitungen sichten die Daten der einzelnen Klassen gemeinsam mit den Lehrkräften und analysieren dabei die Da-ten ihrer Einzelschülerinnen und -schüler, um spezifische Interventionen zu deren Lernförde rung zu planen. Sie gewährleistet, dass das Bildungssystem strategische Ziele erreichen kann  und dass dabei die Fachkräfte auf den unterschiedlichen Systemebenen professionell und zielori entiert zusammenarbeiten (www.cbe.ab.ca).  Die Zuweisung der Mittel für die sonderpädagogische Förderung (darunter auch Hochbe gabung), erfolgt über das sogenannte »Coding «. Schülerinnen und Schüler, für die eine von ei ner vereidigten Diagnostikstelle außerhalb der Schulen angefertigte sonderpädagogische Diagno se existiert, erhalten einen »Code«. An diesem Code hängt jeweils ein bestimmter Finanztransfer an die Schule, die das Kind oder der Jugendliche besucht. Auch multiple Codierungen sind mög lich, sodass z.B. für eine Schülerin oder einen Schüler, die oder der über ein sprachliches und ein körperliches Handikap verfügt, die Finanzmittel von zwei unterschiedlichen Codes an die Schule fließen. Kanada hat sich für einen Mittelweg zwischen den in Deutschland vieldiskutier ten Konzepten der »Kategorisierung« und der »Dekategorisierung« entschieden: Die Mittelzu weisung an die Schulen erfolgt aufgrund der tatsächlich an einer Schule beschulten Individuen mit entsprechender Diagnostik, für die ein oder mehrere Codes jeweils die Mittelzuweisung an die Schule festlegen. Die Codierungen sind streng datenschutzrechtlich geschützt und nur der Schulleitung und den Aufsichtsgremien (Schulaufsicht und Board of Trustees) zugänglich. Anne Sliwka und Britta Klopsch258 der Summe der Codes aller Schülerinnen und Schüler mit Diagnostik ergibt sich das sonderpä dagogische Förderbudget einer Schule für ein bestimmtes Schuljahr. Obwohl dieses Budget sich  aufgrund eines klaren Systems der Diagnostik und des Codings zusammensetzt, wird es nicht »kategorisiert« eingesetzt. Das bedeutet, dass die Finanzmittel nicht den jeweils einzelnen Schü lerinnen und Schülern zugeschrieben sind, sondern dass sich vielmehr durch die Summe aller Codierungen für die Schule ein Gesamtbudget ergibt, das diese als Globalbudget nutzt, um Per sonalkosten für Zusatzpersonal (z.B. Therapiestunden) oder auch Sachkosten (z.B. spezielle di daktische Materialien) zu decken. Auf diese Weise wird sichergestellt, dass Schulen entsprechend ihrer realen Bedarfe ausgestattet sind und die Mittelverteilung zwischen den Schulen als fair wahrgenommen wird (Alberta Education, 2014, 2015). Um die für die Einzelschule benötigten Ressourcen optimal zu integrieren sind die meis ten Schulen in Kanada als sogenannte » Wrap ­around « bzw. » Full Service Schools « (Dryfoos  & Maguire, 2002; Muijs, 2007) organisiert. Dies bedeutet, dass die Schulen Verträge und Ko operationen mit externen Organisationen und Experten eingehen können, um bestimmte Bil dungsressourcen aus dem Umfeld gezielt einsetzen zu können. Auf diese Weise können auch un terschiedliche therapeutische Dienstleistungen in die Bildungsplanung einbezogen werden. Für besondere Therapieund Förderangebote in »Pull-out«-Gruppen stehen an den meisten Schulen spezielle Räume unterschiedlicher Größe zur Verfügung. Daneben kooperieren »Wrap around «Schulen in der Regel mit kulturellen, sportlichen und anderen gesellschaftlichen Einrichtungen und bieten zum Beispiel » mental health «-Kurse an, die einerseits das Selbstbewusstsein und die  psychische Stärke der Kinder unterstützen, andererseits aber auch präventiv gegen Mobbing und andere Formen von Gewalt vorbeugen und bei Problemstellungen unterstützend eingreifen. Im Bereich der Zusammenarbeit mit außerschulischen Partnern existieren für die berufliche Inte gration von Schülerinnen und Schülern häufig sogenannte »Co-operative Education«-Program me, in denen die Schulen Berufspraktika organisieren und begleiten.  Um Lernund Entwicklungsprozesse von Schülerinnen und Schülern gezielt zu fördern,  entwickelten Schulen in Kanada Kommunikationsmuster zwischen Lehrkräften, Schülerin nen und Schülern und Eltern zu einem kontinuierlichen Kommunikationsprozess in der Tria de Schule – Schüler/innen – Eltern weiter (Cooper, 2011). Tradierte Beziehungsmuster zwischen Schule und Familie wurden dabei bewusst durch explizite »Bildungspartnerschaften« ersetzt, die sich durch neuartige und facettenreiche Interaktionsformen auszeichnen, die stets den Lernen den und seinen Lernprozess in den Mittelpunkt stellen. Ziel der Kooperationsprozesse zwischen Schulen und Eltern ist die Stärkung der selbstregulativen Fähigkeiten der Schülerinnen und Schüler. Die Lernenden sollen ihren eigenen Lernprozess aktiv mitgestalten und dabei Verant wortung für ihr Lernen übernehmen. Instrumente zur Stärkung der Schülerverantwortung für das eigene Lernen sind beispielsweise die Student Learning Plans und regelmäßige Bilanzgesprä che. Der Learning Plan  begleitet die Lernenden durch unterschiedliche Phasen ihrer Schulbio grafie bis hin zum Schulabschluss und zum Übergang in Beruf oder Studium. Er ist als Online-Plattform gestaltet und dient der Dokumentation und Reflexion des eigenen Lernens. Learning Plans  sind dialogisch angelegt. Bestimmte Teile sind für die Schülerin/den Schüler und Lehrper son zugänglich, andere für die Schülerin oder den Schüler und ihre bzw. seine Eltern. Zusätzlich finden Bilanzgespräche zwischen Lernenden, Eltern und Lehrkräften statt, sodass Schwierigkei ten im Lernprozess vorausschauend erkannt und gezielt bearbeitet werden können. Wichtigstes Ziel der Gespräche ist die Dokumentation und Anerkennung des individuellen Lernwegs durch die Eltern sowie die Verdeutlichung des Lernund Entwicklungsprozesses für die Lernenden. Mit dem Paradigmenwechsel in der Leistungsbewertung veränderte sich in Kanada auch die  inhaltliche Gestaltung der Schulzeugnisse. Bis vor einigen Jahren enthielten die Zeugnisse Be wertungen zu Schülerleistungen, die in Form von gereihten Zahlen oder Buchstaben den Leis  Handbuch Schulpädagogik, 9783825286989, 2018   wurde mit IP-Adresse 131.188.006.020 aus dem Netz der UB Erlangen-Nürnberg am Februar 17, 2023 um 09:18:04 (UTC) heruntergeladen. Durch die einflussreiche Forschung der Stanforder Psychologin Carol Dweck (2007) zur  Wirkung des Selbstkonzepts auf die Selbstregulation in Lernprozessen wurde deutlich, dass die Form und das Timing von Feedback sowie der Kommunikationsstil, mit dem den Lernenden Feedback erteilt wird, grundlegend beeinflusst, ob und zu welchem Grad sie sich selbst als kom petente Verantwortliche für ihren Lernprozess (»growth mindset «) wahrnehmen. Die traditio nellen kanadischen Ziffernzeugnisse, die den an deutschen Schulen üblichen Zeugnissen sehr ähnlich sind, ließen sich jedoch nicht mehr mit dem Forschungsstand vereinbaren. Problema tisch erschien vor allem, dass sie nicht genügend Informationen enthielten, die Schülerinnen und Schülern sowie Eltern den Korridor aufzeigen, in dem die oder der Lernende lernen und sich entwickeln kann, wenn sie/er versteht, dass sich Leistungen vor allem durch eigene Lernzie le, das strategische Planen des eigenen Lernprozesses und die Übernahme von Verantwortung für das eigene Lernen entwickeln. Als Konsequenz dieser neuen wissenschaftlichen Erkenntnisse wurden statt der klassischen Notenzeugnisse progress report s eingeführt, die die Lernund Leis tungsentwicklung einer Schülerin oder eines Schülers beschreiben. So wurde der Wandel von der sozialen zur individuellen und kriterialen Bezugsnorm nicht nur im alltäglichen Unterricht, sondern auch auf der Ebene einer jährlichen »Lernbilanz« vollzogen. Inhalt und Struktur der Zeugnisse sind dabei nicht nur individuell gestaltet, sondern erlauben, die Leistungsentwicklung einer/s Lernenden im Vergleich zur eigenen Vorleistung und den Bildungsstandards der Provinz zu sehen. Die daraus resultierenden Dialoge zwischen Schülerinnen und Schülern, Eltern und Lehrkräften nehmen das Lernen nicht als Zustand sondern als Prozess wahr, innerhalb dessen der Wissenserwerb grundsätzlich als Potenzialentwicklung angesehen wird. Eine klare Orien tierung der Zeugnisse an outcome-orientierten Bildungsstandards erleichtert hierbei den Aus tausch über das Lernen. Dies bedeutet, dass in jedem Fach keine Note, sondern die Erfüllung von Kompetenzstandards ausgewiesen wird.  Eine Maßnahme, die sich ebenfalls stark am Individuum ausrichtet und zu mehr Bildungs gerechtigkeit führen soll, ist die »flexible high school completion «. Nach diesem Konzept ist es  möglich, die High School, je nach Lernvoraussetzung und persönlicher Situation, nach 12, 12½ oder 13 Jahren abzuschließen. Zentrale Kurse und Klausuren, die nicht mit dem erwarteten Er folg besucht wurden, können wiederholt werden (http://ideas.education. alberta.ca/hsc/; http://inspiring.education.alberta.ca). So werden die kriteriale Bezugsnorm und das Erreichen hoher Bildungsstandards auch beim Schulabschluss konsequent in den Vordergrund gerückt. Das Beispiel Kanadas zeigt, dass sich herkunftsbedingte Bildungsdisparitäten zu einem ge wissen Grad durch strategische Maßnahmen, zum Beispiel die Bestellung diagnostisch und son derpädagogisch geschulten Fachpersonals in multiprofessionellen Teams, passgenaue Förder strategien und Strukturen der inneren Differenzierung an Schulen kompensieren lassen (OECD, 2006; Hargreaves & Shirley, 2012; Stewart, 2012; Alberta Education, 2013). So müssen Chancen gerechtigkeit, Leistungsorientierung und Wohlbefinden von Schülern nicht im Widerspruch zu einander stehen.  Literatur Alberta Assessment Consortium.
